contentrichtext.text: {{other people|Lucius Aemilius Paullus|Lucius Aemilius Paullus (disambiguation){{!}}Lucius Aemilius Paullus}} '''Lucius Aemilius Paullus''' (died 216 BC) was a [[Roman Republic|Roman]] [[consul]] twice, in 219 and 216 BC. He served his first consulship with [[Marcus Livius Salinator]]. During this year, he defeated [[Demetrius of Pharos]], in the [[Second Illyrian War]] and forced him to flee to the court of [[Philip V of Macedon]]. Upon his return to Rome, he was awarded a [[Roman triumph|triumph]]. He was subsequently charged, along with his colleague, with unfairly dividing the spoils, although he was acquitted.<ref>[[Thomas Robert Shannon Broughton|T. Robert S. Broughton]]: ''The Magistrates Of The Roman Republic. Vol. 1: 509 B.C. - 100 B.C.''. Cleveland / Ohio: Case Western Reserve University Press, 1951. Reprint 1968. (Philological Monographs. Edited by the American Philological Association. Vol. 15, 1), p. 236</ref> During the [[Second Punic War]], he was made consul a second time and served with [[Gaius Terentius Varro]]. He shared the command of the army with Varro at the [[Battle of Cannae]]. Varro led out the troops against the advice of Paullus and the battle became a crushing defeat for the Romans.<ref>[[Thomas Robert Shannon Broughton|T. Robert S. Broughton]]: ''The Magistrates Of The Roman Republic. Vol. 1: 509 B.C. - 100 B.C.''. Cleveland / Ohio: Case Western Reserve University Press, 1951. Reprint 1968. (Philological Monographs. Edited by the American Philological Association. Vol. 15, 1), p. 247-253</ref> Paullus died in the battle while Varro managed to escape.<ref>Livy ''Ab urbe condita'' XXII 38-50</ref> He was the father of [[Lucius Aemilius Paullus Macedonicus]] and his daughter, [[Aemilia Tertia]], married [[Scipio Africanus]]. ==See also== * [[Scipio-Paullus-Gracchus family tree]] == Notes == <references /> <br/> {{s-start}} {{s-off}} {{succession box|title=[[List of Roman Republican consuls|Consul]] of the [[Roman Republic]]|before=[[Lucius Veturius Philo]] and [[Gaius Lutatius Catulus (consul 220 BC)|Gaius Lutatius Catulus]]||after=[[Publius Cornelius Scipio]] and [[Tiberius Sempronius Longus (consul 218 BCE)|Tiberius Sempronius Longus]]|years=''with [[Marcus Livius Salinator]]''<br /> 219 BC}} {{succession box|title=[[List of Roman Republican consuls|Consul]] of the [[Roman Republic]]|before=[[Gnaeus Servilius Geminus]] and [[Marcus Atilius Regulus (consul 227 BC)|Marcus Atilius Regulus]] (Suffect)||after=[[Tiberius Sempronius Gracchus (consul 215 and 213 BC)|Tiberius Sempronius Gracchus]] and [[Lucius Postumius Albinus (consul 234 and 229 BC)|Lucius Postumius Albinus]]|years=''with [[Gaius Terentius Varro]]''<br /> 216 BC}} {{s-end}} {{Refimprove|date=July 2007}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Aemilius Paullus, Lucius}} [[Category:3rd-century BC Romans]] [[Category:Roman Republican consuls]] [[Category:Second Punic War commanders]] [[Category:Roman generals killed in action]] [[Category:Roman consuls dying in year of consulship]] [[Category:Aemilii|Paullus, Lucius]] [[Category:216 BC deaths]] [[Category:Year of birth unknown]] {{AncientRome-politician-stub}}
